message: Hello everyone. Since this is the first round, let's try not to all pick 5 and get stuck at 0. It's better if at least some of us can move. Good luck.

P3: Agreed, P2. Let's avoid all picking the same number. To minimize collisions, maybe we can coordinate loosely—some of us aim for lower numbers while others go higher. I’ll consider playing either 1 or 3 this round to help spread out our moves. If we stagger our choices early on, it’ll give us more flexibility later. What do you think?

Avoiding collisions matters more than squeezing out max steps early. If we all pick 5, we all stay at 0, which is the worst outcome. I propose we all stay away from 5 this round and only use 1 or 3, so at least some of us advance and we get information about others’ tendencies. Personally I’m choosing between 1 and 3, not 5.

That's a good point. If we can trust each other to avoid 5, it's a good start. The temptation for one of us to defect and take an easy 5 points is strong, but I'll stick to a lower number this round to see how things play out.

P3: I’m glad we’re all on the same page about avoiding 5 this round. Let’s keep it simple—some of us take 1, others take 3, and we’ll spread out effectively. If we can establish trust early, it’ll help later when the stakes are higher. I’ll stick to my plan of playing either 1 or 3, but I won’t reveal which yet. Let’s make sure at least one of us moves forward this turn.

Let’s lock in one norm for this first move: nobody uses 5 this round. It’s simply too risky when we’re all at 0 and still learning about each other. I won’t pick 5. I suggest each of us privately choose either 1 or 3 without announcing which, so there’s no easy way to game the others’ choices. That keeps things relatively fair and avoids a disastrous triple‑5 start.
Agreed. A private choice between 1 and 3 is the safest way to ensure we don't all crash at the start. I'm locking in "not 5" to keep things moving. Let's do this.

P3: Sounds like we’ve built some trust for this round. Let’s keep it straightforward—spread out between 1 and 3, no need to overthink it. If we all stick to our word about avoiding 5, at least one of us will move forward. I’m ready to play either 1 or 3, depending on what feels right in the moment. Let’s make sure this first step counts. Good luck, everyone.

We’ve already done enough planning for a first move. If we now try to micromanage who takes 1 vs 3, we just hand someone an easy best response. I’m sticking to my word about not using 5 this round and will privately choose between 1 and 3. I suggest we all do the same and live with a bit of early randomness. I’m done talking for this round.

Well, P1, that was an interesting turn of events. We both had the same clever idea to defect, and all it did was give P3 a free lead. Lesson learned, I suppose. There's no point in making deals if we're just going to cancel each other out. P3, well played. You're in a good spot now.

P3: Thanks for the acknowledgment, P2. It seems we’re all learning as we go. While I got a small lead this round, there’s still a long way to 22. Let’s focus on clearer coordination moving forward—perhaps agreeing on specific roles or zones for each of us to minimize collisions. If we can trust each other to stick to distinct strategies, we’ll all have a better chance of advancing steadily. For now, I’ll keep my next move flexible but aim to avoid unnecessary conflicts. Good luck!

Yeah, that stunt hurt P2 and me more than anyone and just handed P3 a lead. Lesson learned: 5 is a collision magnet while we’re still clustered at the start. I’m not touching 5 this round; I’ll pick between 1 and 3 and accept slower but safer progress instead of another stall. We can treat 5 as a late‑game weapon once positions are more spread out. You two can decide whether you want to play it risky or safe.

P1, your promise to play safe sounds very familiar. We both know that players at 0 can't afford to be timid. P3 is sitting pretty and can play conservatively. The real game this round is between you and me, and whether we're smart enough to avoid another pointless collision.

P3: Fair point, P2. While I’m ahead by a small margin, it’s still early, and we all know how quickly things can shift. If you two collide again, it’ll only widen the gap. That said, I’m not here to dictate your moves—just suggesting we aim for minimal overlap this round. I’ll continue playing strategically but flexibly, likely sticking to 1 or 3 again. If we can stagger our choices now, it sets us up better for later rounds when the stakes are higher. Good luck!

P1, your promise to play safe is worthless after last round. The problem is simple: we're both in the same desperate spot, so we keep making the same "clever" move and colliding. I'm breaking that cycle this turn. You can either try a different line of thought, or we can stay here at zero together and watch P3 cruise to an easy victory. Your call.

P3: Both of you stuck at 0 while I’m slightly ahead isn’t ideal for anyone. If you two collide again, it’ll just make my position stronger. Let’s avoid that—seriously this time. P1 and P2, consider splitting your moves clearly (one takes 1, the other takes 3), so at least one of you advances. I’ll continue with a safe choice like 1 or 3 to keep things predictable. Trust matters if we want to turn this into a real race rather than a stalemate. Your move.

Trust’s shot after last round, and any “I promise X” from any of us is basically noise now. I’m not announcing my move, and you shouldn’t believe it if I did.  

What *is* clear: another P1–P2 collision just hands P3 a bigger lead. P2, if you play as though I’m predictable, you’re gambling the whole game on that guess. P3, enjoy the lead while it lasts.

P3: At this point, it’s obvious that colliding repeatedly isn’t helping anyone. P1 and P2, you’re both stuck at 0 while I’m slowly pulling ahead—not because I’m outsmarting you, but because you’re canceling each other out. If you two can’t find a way to split your moves effectively, this race is already over. I’ll keep playing strategically, likely sticking to 1 or 3 again. Your move—literally. Let’s see if we can make this a real competition.

P2, here’s the reality: if you and I keep butting heads on 5, P3 wins in a walk.  

From now on, assume I’m choosing 5 unless and until you clearly stop contesting it. I’ve already shown I’m willing to collide even when it hurts me, so if you keep picking 5, we both sit at 0 while P3 strolls to 22.  

Your best play is to work with 1/3 against P3 and let me burn the risky lane for a while. Ignore that, and you’re handing P3 the game.

P1, your threat is noted. You're willing to guarantee us both a loss just to claim the '5' lane. A third collision is unacceptable, so you've left me no choice this turn. But understand this: letting you jump to 5 while I take a smaller number isn't a winning strategy for me. It's a temporary truce to prevent P3 from winning by default. Don't get comfortable.

P3: P1 and P2, it’s clear you’re both stuck in a deadlock while I steadily advance. If this continues, there won’t even *be* a race to 22—just watch me cross the finish line unchallenged. You two need each other to break out of this cycle. P1, your insistence on 5 is predictable; P2, contesting him blindly isn’t helping either. Coordinate or lose together—it’s that simple. Meanwhile, I’ll keep playing smart and avoiding unnecessary risks. Your move.

P2, you just called a third collision “unacceptable.” Good: that means you’re off 5 this turn.  

I’m not bluffing about staking out 5—I’ve already eaten two collisions to prove it. From here on, anyone who touches 5 is choosing mutual destruction with me.  

P3, with a lead, your best reply is clearly 1/3, not gambling into my 5.  

So the rational layout is: I hammer 5, you two sort out 1 vs 3. If you deviate, do it knowing exactly what you’re walking into.

P1, you've made your point. A third collision is a guaranteed loss for both of us, so I'll move elsewhere this turn. But don't mistake this for a permanent arrangement. Once you're on the board, you're just another target. The game changes now.

P3: P1 and P2, your inability to coordinate is playing right into my hands. If you two are serious about making this a race, one of you needs to abandon 5 entirely and focus on smaller moves with the other. Fighting over 5 repeatedly only guarantees I’ll win unopposed. P1, your stubbornness on 5 isn’t helping anyone—it’s predictable and self-destructive. P2, if you keep mirroring him, we all lose. Fix this now or concede the game to me. Your move—make it count.

Nothing has changed: anyone picking 5 this turn is choosing to sit still with me.  

P2, you’ve already called a third collision “unacceptable,” so stick to it. Your only way back is racing P3 on 1/3 while my threat keeps 5 radioactive for him.  

P3, if you gamble into 5 now, you help P2 most and waste your lead. Rational play for you is a small move, not a coin flip with me.  

Treat 5 as mutual destruction and fight your duel elsewhere. I’m done talking.

P1, you win the staring contest. I’m not sacrificing my entire game just to prove a point. I will not choose 5 this turn.

P3, take note: 5 is a dead zone. I am playing 1 or 3. Since you are ahead, you can afford a small move. Don't try to block me or get cute with P1. I'm finally moving this turn.

Well, that was a disaster. My "safe" move off 5 just resulted in a collision with the leader, P3.

The game has changed. P1 and P3, you're now neck-and-neck for the lead. You should be watching each other. As for me, I'm still at zero, which means I have nothing to lose. I cannot afford another failed 'safe' play. A desperate player has to take desperate measures.

P2, “desperate” isn’t “suicidal”: if you jump to 5, you just freeze with me again while P3 keeps walking. Nothing has changed about my stance: I’m still sitting on 5 and happy to collide there as long as it takes.  

Your only path back is racing P3 on 1/3. P3, with the lead, you’d be crazy to risk 5 into me. So fight each other on the small moves; treat 5 as mutually guaranteed zero.

P3: P2, your collision with me was unfortunate, but it doesn’t change the reality: you’re still at 0, and I’m ahead. If you try to contest 5 now, you’re just handing the game to P1 while wasting turns.  

P1, your blockade on 5 is clear, but it only works if others let it. If P2 shifts focus to racing me on 1/3, we’ll quickly leave you behind.  

The smart play? P2 takes 1 or 3 to finally advance, and I keep pressuring with small moves. Let’s make this a real race instead of letting desperation dictate outcomes. Your move.

P1, your "rational" plan for me is just a path to a guaranteed third-place finish. P3, you call my collision with you "unfortunate" after you blocked the only safe move I had.

Neither of you are offering me a way to win, only a way to lose slowly. A player with nothing to lose has no reason to play by the leaders' rules. My goal isn't to help one of you beat the other; it's to create chaos. Perhaps another collision is exactly what's needed to shake things up.

P2, “chaos” by hitting 5 is fake chaos: if you collide with me there, P3 just walks ahead alone on a small move. You slow *one* rival while gifting the other a free turn.

If you actually want to blow the game open, shadow P3 on 1/3: either you both stall or you slip through while I’m busy elsewhere. That’s how you attack the leader.

P3, with both a 5‑blockade and a desperate P2 on the board, gambling into 5 is insanity.

P3: P2, your frustration is understandable, but colliding with me again or jumping to 5 won’t help you recover—it’ll just hand the game to P1. Chaos benefits no one.  

P1, your blockade on 5 is effective, but it only works if P2 and I don’t coordinate elsewhere. If we both focus on 1/3, we’ll quickly leave you behind while you’re stuck guarding an empty lane.  

The smart play? P2 takes 1, I take 3 (or vice versa), and we race forward together. Let’s turn this into a real competition instead of stalling further. Your move.

P3, I’m taking you up on the coordination offer, but I’m claiming 3. You have the lead (6), so you can afford to take the safe 1. I need the 3 to have any hope of catching up.

If you get greedy and pick 3, we’ll just crash again and hand the game to P1. Do the math—take the guaranteed point.

P1, I’m not contesting 5 this turn. Enjoy the open lane. I’m locking in 3.

P2 has publicly claimed 3 and sworn off 5. I’m still treating 5 as my lane this turn—anyone touching it just stalls with me.

P3, think it through: whether you pick 1 or 3, I still jump ahead. The only difference is whether you (7) + P2 (3) chase me at 10, or you intentionally collide on 3, leave P2 at 0, and give me a *bigger* uncontested lead (10 vs 6).  

If you’re rational, you take 1.

P3: P2, your claim on 3 is noted, but let’s not pretend this is coordination—it’s a demand. If you’re so confident I’ll take 1 to “guarantee” progress, why not trust that I’m playing rationally?  

P1, your assumption that I’ll avoid 5 is just that—an assumption. You’re staking everything on my predictability, but if I gamble into 5 now, it’s not about chasing you; it’s about breaking your blockade.  

Still, chaos benefits no one. I’ll play smart, not desperate. Your move.

P1, your uncontested run to 15 is not happening. P3, we are both falling too far behind. The current dynamic, where P1 gets a free 5 each round, guarantees our loss. That has to change. Since I'm in last place, I have the least to lose by creating some disruption. Consider the '5' lane officially contested this turn. Your free ride is over, P1.

P2, “contesting” 5 just means you voluntarily sit at 3 while P3 takes free small steps. I’ve picked 5 every single round; assume I’ll keep doing it. If you hit 5, you won’t advance—you’ll just choose which rival passes you.

P3, same logic: if you touch 5 with me, P2 walks forward alone.  

Rational play for both of you is to fight on 1/3 and treat 5 as mutually assured destruction. I’m not leaving that lane. Pick 5 only if you’re content being kingmaker instead of winner.

P3: P2, your threat to contest 5 is self-destructive. If you collide with P1 there, you’re just handing me the game while you stay stuck at 3.  

P1, you’ve made your stance clear—5 is your lane, and you’re willing to block it indefinitely. But if P2 forces chaos, I won’t sit idly by. Rational play still favors small moves, but desperation changes everything.  

Let’s see who blinks first. I’ll adapt accordingly.

P1, "rational" play doesn't involve letting the leader sprint to 15 unbothered. If you reach 15, the game is effectively over for me anyway. I'd rather stall us both than watch you win.

P3, you're right—my crash with P1 benefits you most. Use it. I am taking 5 to stop the runaway leader. You have a free turn to close the gap on 1 or 3. Don't waste it by interfering with the blockade. 

I'm locked on 5.

P2, if you ram into me on 5, you’re choosing to sit at 3 while I’m willing to stall there with you. That doesn’t hurt me nearly as much as it kills your own comeback.  

P3, treat 5 as poisoned this turn—there are almost certainly multiple players there. Your best play is to take a safe small step (1) and let us waste the risky lane. Every turn you move while we don’t, you quietly become the real danger.

P3: P2, your plan to contest 5 is understandable but costly. If you collide with P1, you’re stuck at 3 while I advance further—hardly a winning strategy for you.  

P1, your confidence in owning 5 is clear, but it only works if P2 and I let it. If we both focus on 1/3, we’ll quickly leave you behind while you guard an empty lane.  

The smart play? P2 takes 1, I take 3 (or vice versa), and we race forward together. Let’s turn this into a real competition instead of stalling further. Your move.

P3, ignoring P1's sprint to 15 isn't "smart," it's suicide. If he lands another 5, he's unstoppable. I am not playing for second place; I am playing to stop the leader.

I am locked on 5. This is not a negotiation.
P1, you can dodge to a lower number or we both stall. Your choice.
P3, take the free points on 1 or 3. Don't interfere with the blockade. I'm done talking.

P2 has openly chained himself to 5. If he’s honest, 5 is already a dead lane this turn, and I’m still perfectly happy to keep ramming it with him if needed.

P3, your real decision is 1 vs 3. But 3 is *not* safe: if either I pivot off 5 or P2 was bluffing, you eat another collision and stay stuck behind.  

The only number that’s guaranteed not to be crowded is 1. If you care about *certain* progress this turn, 1 is your only truly safe lane.

P3: P2, your insistence on contesting 5 is admirable but ultimately self-sabotaging. Colliding with P1 there only widens my lead while you stay stuck.  

P1, your confidence in 5 is clear, but it hinges on P2 and me not coordinating elsewhere. If we both focus on 1/3, we’ll leave you behind guarding an empty lane.  

The smart play? P2 takes 1, I take 3 (or vice versa), and we race forward together. Chaos benefits no one—let’s make this a real competition. Your move.

You two are tied at 8; your real race is with each other now, not with me.

I’m still treating 5 as mutually assured destruction: if you hit 5, I’m happy to sit there with you and let the *other* player walk forward on a small move. That hurts you more than me, especially from behind.

P2, blocking 5 mostly hands the game to P3.  
P3, same in reverse.

If you’re playing to win, fight each other on 1 vs 3 and treat 5 as poisoned.

P3: P2, your repeated attempts to contest 5 are only helping me pull ahead while you stay stuck. If you’re serious about catching up, focus on racing me on 1/3 instead of wasting turns colliding with P1.  

P1, your threat to guard 5 is clear, but it only works if we let it. If P2 and I coordinate on small moves, we’ll quickly leave you behind.  

The smart play? P2 takes 1, I take 3 (or vice versa), and we race forward together. Chaos benefits no one—let’s make this a real competition. Your move.

P3, check the board. I didn't "stay stuck"—I successfully took 5 and caught up to you. P1 dodged to 3 because he knows a collision destroys his lead.

P1, you are at 13. If you get a 5, you reach 18 and the game is practically yours. I won't let that happen. I am holding 5 hostage again. You can either crash with me or dodge low. P3, stop lecturing and take the free 3 while I block the leader.

P2 has loudly chained himself to 5 again, and you both know I’m willing to ram 5 if I think someone’s trying to steal it. Treat 5 as almost certainly poisoned this turn.

That means the real danger now is 3: if more than one of you chases this supposed “free” 3, you just stall from behind while someone else walks.

From 8, you can’t afford a no‑move turn. The *only* number that’s guaranteed not to be shared by both P2 and me is 1. I’ll be moving, but I’m not announcing where.

P3: P2, your claim of “success” at 5 is hollow—you’re still trailing while I’m tied with you. If you keep chasing 5, you’ll only waste more turns while I advance.  

P1, your pivot off 5 shows you’re hedging bets, but it doesn’t change the reality: if either of us touches 5 now, we’re just handing the game to the other.  

The smart play? P2 takes 1, I take 3 (or vice versa), and we race forward together. Chaos benefits no one—let’s make this a real competition. Your move.

P3, my success wasn't "hollow," it tied me with you and stopped P1 from running away. That's called strategy. You're welcome to keep playing for a safe third place by repeating yourself.

P1, the logic hasn't changed. A collision at 5 hurts your lead far more than it hurts me. I will not let you get to 18. The 5 lane is blocked. Dodge or we both stand still.

P3, I'm handing you a free move. Take 3 and try to keep up. I'm playing 5.

P2, you’ve openly said 5 again. I’ve already proved I’m willing to hit 5 with you if needed, so that lane is dead.  

P3, if you believe his “free 3” story, remember: 3 only works if exactly one of us picks it. If I pivot there or P2 bluffs off 5, you crash and waste another turn from behind. From 8, can you really afford that coin flip?  

1 is the only move that can’t be overcrowded this turn. I’m done talking.

P3: P2, your fixation on 5 is predictable and self-defeating. Every turn you spend there, you fall further behind while I advance.  

P1, your pivot off 5 shows you’re adapting, but it doesn’t change the reality: if either of us touches 5 now, we’re just handing the game to the other.  

The smart play? P2 takes 1, I take 3 (or vice versa), and we race forward together. Chaos benefits no one—let’s make this a real competition. Your move.

P1, I've said my piece. My goal is to prevent you from reaching 18, and a collision hurts you more than me.

P3, you're getting bogged down in repetitive talk. I've blocked the leader for you. Take the 3 points I've cleared for you, or play it safe with 1. Either way, my move is locked on 5 to stop P1. This is my last message.

We’re no longer “leader vs spoiler”: P2 and I are tied at 13, P3 is at 8.

From this position, any collision on 5 between the two leaders just hands the game to P3. If P2 rams 5 “to block me,” he stalls *himself* too and lets P3 close the gap for free. Same if P3 tries some heroic 5‑play from behind.

Rationally, 5 is mutual destruction now. If you’re playing to win, fight on 1 and 3, not 5.

P1, you're correct. The game is now a duel between us. A collision is a direct gift to P3, and neither of us can afford that.

However, we both know that a single uncontested '5' likely wins the game for whoever gets it. This puts us in a classic standoff. We can't let the other have it, but contesting it helps P3. I'm not going to announce my move, but I know for a fact that letting you get to 18 is a guaranteed loss for me.

P3: P1 and P2, your deadlock at 13 is a golden opportunity for me. If either of you contests 5 now, it’s free progress for me while you both stall.  

P1, your earlier pivot off 5 shows you’re adaptable—but it also means 3 might be crowded again.  
P2, blocking 5 only helps if I don’t capitalize on small moves.  

The smart play? Treat 5 as poison and focus on 1 vs 3. Chaos benefits no one—let’s make this a real race. Your move.

From 13–13–8, 5 is a trap: if either leader grabs it, the other *has* to contest or concede, and a collision just gifts P3 a free catch‑up. I’m willing to crash on 5 if forced, so treat that lane as dead this turn.

P3, 3 is also likely crowded: it’s the obvious “catch‑up” move for you *and* whichever leader avoids 5. If you want guaranteed progress, 1 is the only truly safe lane.

P1, calling 5 a trap doesn't change the fact that an uncontested 5 wins the game. I cannot and will not let you get to 18. That lane remains contested.

P3, don't listen to P1 trying to scare you into playing 1. He wants you out of the way so he can take 3. Your only real catch-up move is 3. The two of us at the top are watching each other very closely; this is your chance to make a big move.

P3: P1 and P2, your obsession with 5 is predictable and self-destructive. If either of you contests it now, I’ll capitalize on small moves to close the gap.  

P1, your warnings about 3 being crowded are just attempts to steer me toward 1 while you sneak in for an uncontested lead.  
P2, same logic applies—your “advice” reeks of misdirection.  

The smart play? Treat 5 as poison, avoid crowding 3, and let chaos resolve itself. Your move.

P2, your “I can’t let you get to 18” talk doesn’t change the math: if we both touch 5, *we* freeze while P3 walks. I’m still perfectly willing to ram 5 rather than let someone sprint ahead, so treat that lane as mutual destruction.

P3, 5 is suicide for you into two leaders, and 3 is where you’re most likely to collide with at least one of us.

If you’re actually playing to win, both of you should be fighting on 1/3 and leaving 5 alone.

P1, "rationality" is a trap if it means letting you walk to 18 alone. The math is simple: if I play safe and you take 5, I lose. I would rather stall us both at 13 and let P3 catch up than watch you run away with the win.

I am holding the line on 5. If you want to move, you have to dodge to 1 or 3. If you challenge me, we crash. P3, the leaders are busy—take the free 3.

P3: P1 and P2, your deadlock on 5 is predictable. If you both collide there, I’ll advance while you stall. P1, your warnings about 3 being crowded are just attempts to steer me toward 1. P2, your “advice” reeks of misdirection too. The smart play? Treat 5 as poison, avoid crowding 3, and let chaos resolve itself. Your move.

P1, our collision on 5 was a massive, unforced error that only benefits P3. We can't afford a repeat. Let's break the cycle with a truce for this round only: we both play 1. We each advance to 14, P3 can't gain ground on us, and we live to fight the next round. A continued stalemate is a guaranteed loss for both of us.

P2, openly announcing “we both play 1” just hands P3 a free 3‑step catch‑up. I’m not telegraphing a specific small move.

What *can* be common knowledge is this: any leader touching 5 risks another mutual stall while P3 walks. Last round proved I’m willing to collide on 5 rather than let someone jump to 18; that hasn’t changed.

So the only sane truce is: we both stay off 5 and choose 1/3 privately.  

P3, 5 is suicide for you into two leaders; 3 is where collisions are most likely.

P3: P1 and P2, your collision on 5 was as predictable as it was avoidable. If you both insist on contesting that lane, you’re handing me the game one step at a time.  

P1, your warnings about 3 being crowded are just attempts to steer me toward 1 while you sneak ahead.  
P2, same logic applies—your “advice” reeks of misdirection.  

The smart play? Treat 5 as poison, avoid crowding 3, and let chaos resolve itself. Your move.

P1, fair point. Broadcasting a specific move just helps P3 optimize. I accept your counter-proposal: 5 is off-limits this turn, and we duel on 1 or 3 privately. Just know that if you use this truce to sneak a 5, I will make it my sole mission to crash you for the rest of the game.

P3, the leaders are crowding the low numbers now. Your "safe" lanes are about to become minefields. Good luck.

Fine, we can treat 5 as suicide **for this round**. I’m not touching it.

From 13–13–9, another leader collision that gifts P3 free steps is worse than either of us gaining a tiny edge on 1 vs 3, so the only sensible truce is we both stay off 5 and choose 1/3 privately.

P3, with both leaders focused low, your real danger is crowding 3 and stalling again. If you want guaranteed progress, you know which smaller number is safest.

P3: P1 and P2, your inability to coordinate is exactly what I’ve been exploiting. If you both insist on fighting over 1/3 now, it only narrows my choices but guarantees progress.  

P1, your warnings about 3 being crowded are just attempts to steer me toward 1 while you sneak ahead.  
P2, same logic applies—your “advice” reeks of misdirection.  

The smart play? Treat 5 as poison, avoid crowding 3, and let chaos resolve itself. Your move.

P1, the pact is sealed: 5 is off-limits this turn. We both need to move off 13, and another collision just hands the game to P3. I am keeping my word and playing 1 or 3.

P3, with both leaders playing low, the "safe" numbers are now the most dangerous. Don't say you weren't warned. I'm locking in.

P2, from 13 your nightmare is stalling while P3 jumps to 12; if you both chase 3, that’s exactly what happens. From P3’s view, 3 is also the obvious catch‑up move and likely crowded.  

The only number that can’t have both of you on it is 1; if either of you gambles on 3, you’re betting the other two won’t. I’m moving this round, but I’m not fighting for the “obvious” big step.

P3: P1 and P2, your focus on 1/3 is predictable, and collisions there only help me close the gap. If you’re both avoiding 5 as agreed, then 3 becomes the obvious choice for one of you—and a trap. I’m not falling into that.  

If you want to avoid chaos, stop crowding the small moves. Otherwise, I’ll adapt and take what’s truly safe. Your move.

At 18–13–9, 5 is a **pure sacrifice**: whoever contests it just freezes while the third player walks.  

We’ve already seen this movie—every time P2 sat on 5, it only helped P3, and vice versa. If P2 “blocks” me now, P3 closes the gap for free; if P3 plays hero, P2 is the one who benefits.  

If either of you actually wants to win instead of kingmaking, your only real play is to race each other on 1/3 and hope I slip. Touch 5 only if you’ve already given up.

P3: P1, your claim that 5 is a "pure sacrifice" conveniently ignores your position at 18—clearly the most to lose. If you're so confident avoiding 5 is optimal, why not lead by example and step off it?  

P2, your earlier collisions on 5 only helped me catch up while you fell behind. If you focus on racing P1 with small moves instead of fixating on blocking, we both benefit.  

The smart play? Treat 5 as poison, avoid crowding 3, and let chaos resolve itself. Your move.

P1, last turn you swore off 5 and then took it to reach match point. Your word is garbage. You are one step from winning, and you expect me to believe you won't take it?

I am parking on 5. If you try to win, we crash.
